title: Wind in the Willows First Edition 1908 Cover
content:
I've been trying to identify this lettering, and while I seem to find the right "W", I can't seem to get a single match that is right for everything --especially the "H" and the "S." Any ideas? (And thanks for anything that might be offered!)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140527155623im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Wind%20in%20the%20Willows1_3509.jpg)
author: Kurt

comments.content:
Hand lettering in the style of the era. Note the variations in repeating letters.  
The beaked terminals on \_T\_ and \_S\_ are distinctive, but are found in some fonts of the 1900s. Also with \_E\_ similar to the title. For example check the fonts at Greater Albion Typefounders [http://www.myfonts.com/foundry/Greater\_Albion\_Typefounders/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140527155623/http:/www.myfonts.com/foundry/Greater_Albion_Typefounders/ "http://www.myfonts.com/foundry/Greater\_Albion\_Typefounders/") and you might find something you like. Note the similarities with Bonning, Bonaventure and Vertrina.  
Other similars include Canada Type's Ronaldson [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/ronaldson/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140527155623/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/ronaldson/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/ronaldson/") and Intellecta's Benjamin Franklin [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/benjamin-franklin/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140527155623/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/benjamin-franklin/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/benjamin-franklin/")  
Don

Don:

Thank you! I am sure to find what is needed from what you have offered. I noted the variation, but never thought about hand lettering. It is a lesson for me to better consider the period of the piece.

With my regards,  
Kurt
